name: Blog post layout
title: Blog post layout

files.name: components/blog-post-layout.tsx
app/globals.css
app/page.tsx
files.content:
import { BlogPostLayout } from "@/components/blog-post-layout" // Example content const sampleContent = `

Hearts of Iron IV

Naval AI Crisis

The community has raised significant concerns about the naval AI behavior in recent patches. Players report that enemy fleets make illogical decisions and fail to protect vital supply lines.

  • AI admirals refuse to engage when they have numerical superiority
  • Convoy raiding mechanics remain fundamentally broken
  • Naval invasions are either too easy or impossible depending on the patch
"I've been playing since launch and this is the worst state naval combat has ever been in. The AI simply doesn't understand how to use its fleet." — Community member on the official forums

DLC Quality Concerns

The latest DLC release has received mixed reviews, with many players questioning the value proposition compared to previous expansions.

  • Limited new mechanics for the price point
  • Focus tree additions feel shallow compared to earlier DLCs
  • Performance issues introduced with the latest update

Victoria 3

Economic Simulation Depth

Players have praised the economic simulation as one of the most sophisticated in any grand strategy game, though some feel it lacks the military depth of its predecessors.

"The economy system is brilliant, but I miss the detailed military planning from Victoria 2. Everything feels too automated now." — Steam review
  • Trade routes and market dynamics feel organic and responsive
  • Population management creates meaningful strategic choices
  • Diplomatic plays system needs refinement
` export default function Page() { return ( ) }

messages.content:
You're styling a blog post layout for gaming industry sentiment reports.
The content is markdown-rendered HTML with:
- H2 section headers (game names like "Hearts of Iron IV", "Victoria 3")
- H3 subheaders (topics like "Naval AI Crisis", "DLC Quality Concerns")
- Bullet point lists
- Blockquotes (community quotes)
- Horizontal rules between sections

The component receives: title, date, contentHtml (rendered markdown string).
Use Tailwind CSS. Make it visually engaging and clear, not flat.


Design direction: DARK ACCENTS
- Light background but with dark/bold accent elements
- Section headers could have dark background pills or underlines
- Strong visual hierarchy through weight and color contrast
- Refined, slightly serious/professional tone
- Think Bloomberg or Financial Times style

I've created a professional blog post layout with strong dark accents and clear hierarchy. The design features dark pill-style backgrounds for game name headers (H2), bold underlined subheaders (H3), custom bullet points with square markers, and blockquotes with thick left borders. The typography uses the existing Geist font with careful spacing and weight variations to create a refined, Bloomberg-style reading experience. The layout is fully responsive and works beautifully on all screen sizes.

import { BlogPostLayout } from "@/components/blog-post-layout" // Example content const sampleContent = `

Hearts of Iron IV

Naval AI Crisis

The community has raised significant concerns about the naval AI behavior in recent patches. Players report that enemy fleets make illogical decisions and fail to protect vital supply lines.

  • AI admirals refuse to engage when they have numerical superiority
  • Convoy raiding mechanics remain fundamentally broken
  • Naval invasions are either too easy or impossible depending on the patch
"I've been playing since launch and this is the worst state naval combat has ever been in. The AI simply doesn't understand how to use its fleet." — Community member on the official forums

DLC Quality Concerns

The latest DLC release has received mixed reviews, with many players questioning the value proposition compared to previous expansions.

  • Limited new mechanics for the price point
  • Focus tree additions feel shallow compared to earlier DLCs
  • Performance issues introduced with the latest update

Victoria 3

Economic Simulation Depth

Players have praised the economic simulation as one of the most sophisticated in any grand strategy game, though some feel it lacks the military depth of its predecessors.

"The economy system is brilliant, but I miss the detailed military planning from Victoria 2. Everything feels too automated now." — Steam review
  • Trade routes and market dynamics feel organic and responsive
  • Population management creates meaningful strategic choices
  • Diplomatic plays system needs refinement
` export default function Page() { return ( ) }
